docs.lead_paragraph: Ben Carson pitched a tax plan with numbers that didn't add up. Donald Trump boasted that he's paying his own way in the campaign, but he isn't. Chris Christie accused the government of stealing Social Security money that it has actually borrowed — and has been paying back with interest.

headline.main: AP FACT CHECK: The Republican Debaters and the Facts
headline.print_headline: AP FACT CHECK: The Republican Debaters and the Facts

docs.lead_paragraph: Boardwalks have been rebuilt, sea walls erected, bays cleared of debris and thousands of homes restored three years after Superstorm Sandy pummeled coasts of New Jersey and New York. Yet the rebuilding effort is not finished. Many homes still need to be repaired or rebuilt. Crucial work to shore up infrastructure is ongoing, or still hasn't started.

headline.main: 3 Years After Superstorm Sandy, What's Fixed and What's Not
headline.print_headline: 3 Years After Superstorm Sandy, What's Fixed and What's Not

docs.lead_paragraph: Walgreens will use its $9.41 billion takeover of rival Rite Aid to spread its philosophy on making drugstores destinations for customers looking to stay healthy or buy beauty products.

docs.lead_paragraph: Drugstore chain Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc said on Tuesday it would acquire smaller peer Rite Aid Corp for $9.4 billion to widen its footprint in the United States and negotiate for lower drug costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Las Vegas police said Wednesday they have reopened an investigation into the death of a spa worker who was found dead in a cryotherapy chamber.

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget agreement reached this week will prevent a spike in Medicare premiums and a deep cut in Social Security benefits, experts said, but offers no long-term solution for either program.

headline.main: Agreement Is Seen as Short-Term Relief for Medicare and Social Security
headline.print_headline: Agreement Is Seen as Short-Term Relief for Medicare and Social Security

docs.abstract: Lawmakers and budget experts say new federal budget deal will stop steep increase in Medicare premiums for older Americans and large cut in Social Security benefits for disabled workers, but will not change long-term prospects for either program.
docs.snippet: The budget agreement reached this week will prevent a spike in Medicare premiums and a deep cut in Social Security benefits, experts said, but offers no long-term solution for either program.
